channel.title: Google Drive
channel.description:
So I have always used Skydrive/kept an external HD for files.
Somebody messaged me and told me to check out Google Drive. Opinions of it? Is it really the best file sharing service out there?
The files would probably consist of business and home files so I would need capabilities of making folders and etc. What type of security does Google Drive offer as well?

item.title: Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @Kanalith Kanalith
item.description:
@Kanalith wrote:

Google Drive seems to be doing pretty well. I use it for school stuff mostly like if I don’t have the time to turn in a paper work by hand to a teacher; I can just create a folder in Google Drive, upload the file - and share it with her.

Though, if you’re asking for opinions, I highly suggest you to use it for school only since it’s a huge benefit. But then, if you are curious of what you could do besides using it for school… one of the things that I do is upload as many things as I want to my own Google Drive folder, and then log-in with my phone and download those files. So, it means that instead of doing everything manually, I can just download the files from my phone in a matter of seconds.

But it’s hardly surprising that the internet ‘‘giant’’ has moved to what we have now, Google Drive. As you may know, Google seems to do everything these days.

I hope that helped.
Good luck.

Read full topic

item.title: Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Cruel Truth, post:19, topic:482015”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=600254.msg4218204#msg4218204 date=1360531355]
You would be foolish to compare an external harddrive to cloud services. They are entirely different in all capacities of the concept. If you want your stuff backed up so it will never go away, go with cloud services. There’s nothing wrong with dropbox or google drive for just your small personal stuff. Many businesses use google docs, which is a google drive technology. It is reliable.
[/quote]If the above post though that linked to a blog concerning them “profiting from your ideas in docs” then why would I even want to do that? I work in a factory where process improvement can globally profit somebody if it came down to it.[/quote]

Because the point of the blog is to expose paranoia in people looking for those sort of things. People are over-paranoid about cloud services. Many companies use google docs, which is a cloud service that uses google drive. If it was worth being paranoid, why would so many companies decide to use it?

Read full topic

item.title: Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @Cruel_Truth Cruel Truth
item.description:
@Cruel_Truth wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:15, topic:482015”]Compare the T&Cs http://womstech.com/2012/04/25/terms-of-service-for-drive-skydrive-dropbox-and-box-compared/

I’m a fan of everything Google, but they just seemed a bit shady on the launch of Drive.[/quote]Wait I am confused now does this imply that Google and etc can view my files and make money off of it by like selling any business ideas and etc?

If so, I think it’s time to invest into a external HD >.<

Read full topic

item.title: Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Cruel Truth:

they would have some sort of backup offered?

Dropbox has file history, I can’t remember exact figures, but anything that is deleted will be kept on their servers for quite some time. I think for paid members the time is unlimited.

Oh and also, Dropbox has native two step verification, just needs enabling: https://www.dropbox.com/help/363/en

Read full topic

item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

I love Google Drive, I use it for all school assignments because it essentially has Microsoft Office, and it’s wonderful for file storage.

item.title: Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @Cruel_Truth Cruel Truth
item.description:
@Cruel_Truth wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:3, topic:482015”]The T&Cs of Drive make me skeptical, at least they did when it was first introduced, not sure whether they’ve changed or not.

Have you not checked out Dropbox? I’ve got 8GB of free storage with them, and it’s perfect for syncing between my numerous machines at home, work and university.

If I ever needed more than that however (for backup purposes perhaps, currently use a 2TB NAS and a local 1TB external), I would definitely consider Google Drive, as its prices are extremely competitive.[/quote]I honestly just don’t like Dropbox that much. It doesn’t “seem” secure really. I mean an email/password is all you need to do any major damage.

While it is the same with Google Drive I’m sure I would imagine for premium users they would have some sort of backup offered?

I don’t know with me working part time in the actual warehouse and part time in the actual office I need something that is dependable to be up when I need it, that is secure(considering we are talking about government), and something that would even possibly offer backups even if it costed more.

Read full topic

item.title: Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

The T&Cs of Drive make me skeptical, at least they did when it was first introduced, not sure whether they’ve changed or not.

Have you not checked out Dropbox? I’ve got 8GB of free storage with them, and it’s perfect for syncing between my numerous machines at home, work and university.

If I ever needed more than that however (for backup purposes perhaps, currently use a 2TB NAS and a local 1TB external), I would definitely consider Google Drive, as its prices are extremely competitive.

Read full topic

item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

I think Google Drive is going to turn out really well, since Google is making some excellent Android devices it would make sense to have a decent cloud storage to go along with it.
